publications.name: OptimCLM: Optimizing clinical language models for predicting patient outcomes via knowledge distillation, pruning and quantization
publications.publisher: Elsevier - International Journal of Medical Informatics
publications.description:
This research presents OptimCLM, a groundbreaking framework designed to optimize Clinical Language Models (CLMs) for real-world healthcare applications. By combining knowledge distillation, pruning, and quantization, the framework significantly reduces computational overhead while maintaining strong predictive performance.

Key highlights:
- Achieved 22.88Ã— compression and 28.7Ã— inference speedup with <5% performance degradation.
- Outperformed state-of-the-art models on key clinical tasks: mortality prediction, length of stay prediction, procedure prediction, and diagnosis prediction using the MIMIC-III clinical database.
- Showcased the feasibility of deploying AI models in resource-constrained healthcare environments.

This work demonstrates the potential of optimized CLMs in enhancing clinical decision-making and improving healthcare resource utilization.

publications.name: Predicting life satisfaction using machine learning and explainable AI
publications.description: Life satisfaction is a crucial facet of human well-being. Hence, research on life satisfaction is incumbent for understanding how individuals experience their lives and influencing interventions targeted at enhancing mental health and well-being. Life satisfaction has traditionally been measured using analog, complicated, and frequently error-prone methods. These methods raise questions concerning validation and propagation. However, this study demonstrates the potential for machine learning algorithms to predict life satisfaction with a high accuracy of 93.80% and a 73.00% macro F1-score. The dataset comes from a government survey of 19000 people aged 16-64 years in Denmark. Using feature learning techniques, 27 significant questions for assessing contentment were extracted, making the study highly reproducible, simple, and easily interpretable. Furthermore, clinical and biomedical large language models (LLMs) were explored for predicting life satisfaction by converting tabular data into natural language sentences through mapping and adding meaningful counterparts, achieving an accuracy of 93.74% and macro F1-score of 73.21%. It was found that life satisfaction prediction is more closely related to the biomedical domain than the clinical domain. Ablation studies were also conducted to understand the impact of data resampling and feature selection techniques on model performance. Moreover, the correlation between primary determinants with different age brackets was analyzed, and it was found that health condition is the most important determinant across all ages. The best performing Machine Learning model trained in this study is deployed on a public server, ensuring unrestricted usage of the model. We highlight the advantages of machine learning methods for predicting life satisfaction and the significance of XAI for interpreting and validating these predictions.

publications.name: Shadow: A Novel Loss Function for Efficient Training in Siamese Networks
publications.description: In this research, we proposed a novel loss function for efficient training in Siamese networks using projection instead of Eucledian distance. I implemented the whole experimental pipeline in Pytorch and experimented with various datasets to show that this approach gives better performance in terms of both accuracy and efficiency.

member.occupation: Graduate Teaching & Research Assistant @ Johns Hopkins | Improving Lives with Technology | Bridging Academia and Industry with AI/ML

projects.description:
Developed and published OptimCLM, a novel framework designed to optimize Clinical Language Models (CLMs) for deployment in real-world healthcare systems. The framework employs advanced techniques such as knowledge distillation, pruning, and quantization to achieve significant reductions in model size and inference time while maintaining robust predictive performance. Key features of the project include:

- Achieved 22.88Ã— model compression and 28.7Ã— inference speedup with minimal performance loss (<5%).
- Enhanced domain-specific knowledge transfer through ensemble learning using state-of-the-art models like COReBERT and DischargeBERT.
- Demonstrated superior performance on key clinical tasks: mortality prediction, length of stay prediction, procedure prediction, and diagnosis prediction using MIMIC-III clinical database.

This research was published in the International Journal of Medical Informatics and has practical applications in optimizing healthcare resource utilization, enabling real-time clinical decision-making, and deploying AI on resource-constrained edge devices.
projects.title: Optimizing Clinical Language Models
